text: Hello and welcome to the Rest is Football with me, Garel Inneke. I'm joined of course by Alan Shearer and Micah Richards. We've got a special episode for you today that's a little bit different from those that we've done before. That's because we've got a certain guest joining us a little later on. This is something we're going to look to do throughout the season on the Rest is Football. Whenever there's a big topical talking point going on within the sport, we'll get someone on to help us look into them in a bit more detail and give their expert insight. Following the opening weekend of the Premier League, it was, well, the same old story, wasn't it really, with the VAR dominating the headlines once I'm pleased to say that Howard Webb, the PGMOL's Chief Refereeing Officer, is joining us later in the show to help us reflect on some of those decisions and understand what is going on this season. Before we get Howard on though, I want to look back at some of the major talking points and the big story of the week of course is that the Lionesses are in the World Cup final. How about that? What an achievement. They played so well in that game against Australia, didn't they? We had a conversation about their form and gradually it's got better and better and better. Obviously the big conundrum is Lauren James. She got suspended for two games. Now she's available for the final. But Ella Toon in that position, she was outstanding. She took a finish excellently well. The way she just bent it. When the ball comes to you like that, you lot are a better player to talk about it than me. But there's only one way you could hit it to make it go in the top. You sort of like brush across the ball and it was an outstanding finish. The three centre halves, Greenwood, Bright and Carter have been exceptional this tournament as well. And just a real good feel good factor around the team. At times, you're worrying how they're going to set up. But Serena Vigman, she always has a way. And just getting to the final is a massive achievement. So well done the Lionesses. Are you bringing Lauren James back in? That's a conundrum. I mean, it's one of those games where the final in any final is always tense. And the game is going to be open in the second half. So keep it tight and then bring on Lauren James to get the winner or change the game. So I would keep the winning team from the semi-final. What would you lot do? I was playing in a Pro-Am with Lee Westwood. There's a big tournament going on at my local course, Close House, the International Series England and the Asian Tour. And it's a really good feeling. I was lucky enough to play in the Pro-Am there on Wednesday. Whilst the game was going on, I said to the tournament director on the first tee, I said, I know you're not meant to have phones on the course, but it cannot stop me having a phone today with England in the semi-final. It was my excuse for being shit anyway, because I kept checking my phone. And Alan, I have to say, it's great that the two are in a final. Yeah, it's just, it's magnificent. And I mean, when you're looking at the viewing figures for people watching on television, again, they've captured the nation, the country, and everyone's supporting them. It's great to see. And what a morning Sunday is going to be, isn't it? Eleven o'clock kickoff here in England. And wow, what an opportunity again for them. It's just magnificent. Yeah. Spain, of course, in the final. It's a horrible question to ask. Are they going to do it? We've got to back them. We've backed them all the way, haven't we? And Mike is right. We've said that. We've mentioned about form and just getting through the tournament stage by stage, and they've been able to do that and the performances have picked up. So judging by that, they're going to get better again in the final. And of course, they're going to do it. I'll just say a couple of things. I mean, A, the finishing was superb, wasn't it? All three goals were exceptional. But a word for the goalkeeper, because they often, in the past few years, the goalkeepers in the women's game have got a lot of stick. But I think the goalkeeping in this tournament has showed how much they've improved. And Mary Earps, I mean, she's a hell of a keeper, isn't she? Outstanding again. I've worked with her in doing some TV work and she's, I think what makes her so good is her own self-belief. She's had a tough run and she wasn't always number one for England. It's only because one of the goalkeepers got injured and she took a chance and it's a confident self-belief that just makes her believe how good she is. And she performs well. She's good with her feet. She makes some outstanding saves. And you know what it is? She's calm under pressure. That's what I love about her. Every time someone goes through, she just does a job. She's not after the limelight. She just does her job. So yeah, she's been great. You'd back her in a penalty shootout as well, wouldn't you? Indeed, I would, Alan. Well, they've already won one of those. You mentioned calmness there and I think that's probably the thing that comes out for me the most of this particular team. They do seem to have a calm. They don't get overexcited. They don't seem to get too nervous. They don't over-celebrate perhaps when they score and they don't seem to be affected when things go against them a little bit in the game. Yeah, but that comes from the manager, doesn't it, Gary? I think that started long before the tournament because as we know that with the issues through injuries that they had, she never panicked, did she? It was just like, yep, we've got to accept it. We've got to take it. It's happened. We just got to move on. And I think that all comes from the manager. Well, let's all wish them all the very best in the final. It's been a long time since England won a football World Cup. It would be truly special, but whatever happens, they've definitely done us proud in this tournament. One other issue that's happened in midweek since we last spoke is that Manchester City, Mica, have won another trophy, the Supercop. Yeah, I mean, watching Manchester City now, they're obviously a great team, but Kevin de Bruyne gets a big injury. Gunderwands left. And it seems to me like they're just not, they're not in a groove. It's early stages. Manchester City always take a little bit time to get going. They have all that possession, but it just feels like to me that something is missing at this moment in time. Haaland was making so many runs in this game against Seville. Seville was a very good team, very compact, know how to defend. But there seems like there's a link between the midfield and the tack that is missing. I was so happy for Cole Palmer. He scored in the Community Shield and he gets another goal. And it was strange that the interview after with Pep, he's basically saying he's not going on loan. He's either for sale or he's going to be with the squad, which I thought was interesting. They've been linked with Packatar and I really do like him, but he's not got to the heights I thought he would before Manchester City was interested. So it's going to be intriguing to see how the season pans out in terms of creativity. Cole Palmer, I mean, it's a hell of a start for the season for him. So do you think he can grab a place in that team, Haaland? He can get a place in it, but there's no way he's going to replicate what Kevin de Bruyne can do. I mean, and it would be unfair of us to even suggest that because we've been going on and on and rightly so about Kevin de Bruyne and how brilliant he is and one of the best players in the world and how much we as forwards would like to be on the end of his passes. So it wouldn't be fair of us to say he's going to come in and do what he can do, but there's no doubt about it. He brings a certain and a different talent to that team and he's had a great start to the season. Mike had just said with his goal a couple of weeks ago, his goal again on Wednesday evening. Yeah, he's an exceptional player, but there's no way he's filling de Bruyne's boots. Since we last spoke, of course, the other side in Manchester have been in action. They played Wolves on Monday night. Now, we all thought Wolves had struggled this season. I actually had them in my bottom three, but I thought they played so well in that game. I was thinking about changing my mind. The only thing that worries you about Wolves is they couldn't finish off a bag of crisps, could they? Really? They had so many chances in that game, but boy did they play well. Yeah, and when you consider the small amount of time that Gary Neal has had to work with his team, I thought they were really well organised. They're obviously all on the same page, but yeah, their big problem last season, scoring goals and again the other night, it looks as if that's going to be the same thing again. They created so much. They did so well and of course they were robbed with a decision, which I'm sure we're going to get on to, but overall in general, I thought a lot of their player was excellent. Matthias Cunha was, his performance was extraordinary. He just couldn't finish it off, but that aside, he caused havoc in United's midfield in particular. Really? Well, I only seen the first half because you've probably seen this week, I've been at Old Trafford taking penalties. We're getting on to that. Don't you worry by the way. We're getting on to that. I can tell you my record is still zero goals at Old Trafford. We know what your record is. It's fucking useless. Micah, is it true that you're just a shit Gary Neal shit? We heard the crowd singing. Was it embarrassing or was it fun? No, it was absolutely amazing. We did a little bit of training beforehand. It didn't look like it. Explain to people first, Micah, explain to people first what you were doing and why on earth you were taking penalties at Old Trafford. Well, I didn't know we was allowed to promote different people on there, so I was sort of leaving that out, but it was for League of the Roam. That's fine. You can promote what you want on here. It's how we're doing. So we're sure we can do what we want, Micah. Wonderful. I feel free. Free. So, okay, let's go back to the beginning. One of the regulars on League of the Roam. As you know, League of the Roam is a fun sports program. So someone came up with the idea. Don't be jealous, Alan. Don't be jealous. So someone came up with the idea of going to Old Trafford, me being Manchester City and Jamie Redknapp being obviously Liverpool, taking penalties at half time. So before that, we had three hours training at the cliff. And for those who don't know, it's old Man United training ground. So much history there. Brilliant. So in training, I was slotting them left, right, dink, whatnot. Okay. We arrive at Old Trafford. And you know what it's like at Old Trafford? You get a certain part of love. The fans are nice and whatnot. And you just get them ones who are just looking at you like, what the fuck are you doing here? So we go out there, we get changed. We're walking down and we're getting so much abuse. What are you doing? What is this fucking shit? What has Old Trafford become now? It's an absolute joke. So the aim is we get three penalties each and we have to score basically the most. And whoever loses has to wear a Man United shirt. So I go up, I go first, don't I? So I'm going down the touch line and I'm getting abused. I'm getting abused. All sorts. But then the fans started quite enjoying it. So giving me a bit, but like clapping me and all that. And then I got that thing, you lot, see we've talked about my penalty before and I thought to myself, just relax, just relax. What did I do with the first one? I hit the post. Right side of the keeper, the second one, the keeper saves to the keeper's left. Please tell me you got the third one in. And the third one, he saved us. Micah, I wouldn't be too worried about the penalty, Mrs. I'd be more worried about that fucking tight top you had on. It was tight, wasn't it? I thought it was a spray on it was that tight. So I presume that you had to wear the Manchester United top then because surely, surely he scored one, didn't he Red Knapp? Red Knapp scored two and he shanked one. He had to do it, didn't he? Look at me, I'm JB Red Knapp, absolutely melt. It must have been quite embarrassing having to work, not only having not scored one, but also having to put a United top on. Must have been hard. It was horrible. And it's not the first time I've done that as well. Shocking. But never again. I'm never doing anything like that again. I think we all tipped Manchester United to be in the top four. Did it put you off? Because they were, I mean, I know they got three points, Alan, but I mean, and it's so early in the season, but they looked, I mean, they looked very vulnerable, particularly midfield. They were overrun a bit. Yeah, I tend to wait for half a dozen games to be gone before I start and alter or change my predictions or opinions of what's going to happen. But yeah, it looked as if they've got a lot of work to do, particularly in the midfield area, because they were outplayed, out-thought, out-thought. And they looked second best in the midfield area. So that would be a bit of a concern for me, for Man United. And of course, there was that extraordinary decision at the end. And that's the reason that, well, one of the reasons, because we want to talk about perhaps the new laws a little bit, but more about how VAR will work. And after the break, we'll talk to Howard Webb about that. So let's take a breather. Welcome back to the Rest is Football with me, Garry Lineker, Micah Richards and Alan Shearer. And I'm delighted to say we're joined by Howard Webb, who is obviously in charge of all things VAR these days and referees. And Howard, it's been an interesting opening weekend for you. But before we come to discussing those things, I think we should address the elephant in the room, because the certain Alan Shearer still blames you for losing him his job. Explain yourself, please, Howard. Alan, it's taken 10 years, but obviously people are talking about acknowledging errors at the moment. And I do have to acknowledge that error. I blame Kevin Nolan. What happened, Howard? It was Newcastle Fulham. By the way, I'm not totally to blame. I only refereed one of those games that you were in charge for. But yeah, Kevin had been standing on the toes of Mark Schwarzer at corners. And I had a word with Kevin, and this corner was awarded. And I saw him do it again. So I stopped it. You see referees blowing the whistle, going in, having a word and what have you. So I did that. And I said, look, don't do it. Don't stand on his toes. Anyway, so as the corners coming in, he moves towards Schwarzer. I just reacted too quickly and blew. And he kind of just stopped short of doing it. And Mark Viduka slammed this shot into the top corner, like majestically, as I'm blowing the whistle thinking, oh my goodness, I've blown too soon. And no VAR, no opportunity to change it. And I spent the rest of the day thinking, I hope Newcastle come back into this game. And they didn't. And I ended up having to send a player off for a professional foul as well, a dog's hole thing. And Newcastle lost. And then I think you went to Villa on the last day, Alan, needing a win or a point. I can't remember. And you didn't obviously get it. And I remember I was down at West Ham on the same day, thinking, coming off the field, thinking, I hope Newcastle have got something out of the game because otherwise that is going to be, you know, that's going to be pretty significant, that decision to disallow that goal. Do you forgive him, Alan? Well, we did get relegated. And that goal did cost us a point. And we only got relegated by a point. So, but don't worry, Howard, I don't hold fucking grudges. You're all right. Well, I think we could swear. You can swear. You can do what you want on it. We'll do what we want. It's a podcast. You have to forgive him. Thanks for coming on anyway. Thank you. Yeah, very much so. Howard, I suppose as it's time for kind of admitting mistakes, you did so with one at the weekend. Well, it's actually Monday night, wasn't it? Manchester United was probably the biggest, most controversial decision at the weekend. You recognised that was a mistake. Yeah, yeah, we did. Obviously, like any club going into a new season, we want to start well, we want to start strong. And, you know, we've obviously done a lot of prep work in the pre-season and we're actually cranking up our VAR training more than ever before as well. So we were actually in the VAR hub on Friday, going through quite a few situations and just trying to drive that consistency. And we have a philosophy about how we use VAR. I think you're familiar with it. It's around VAR not re-refereeing the game, but sitting there to protect against those clear errors. And we saw a clear error on Monday night, late in the game. I was actually at the game and it looked a penalty, honestly speaking, from where I was sitting in the stand. And I expected when it wasn't given, the referee to go to the screen and have a look at it and then give the penalty. And when that didn't happen, obviously it was really disappointing. The VAR looked at it, saw that neither the goalkeeper or the Wolves player made contact with the ball. Dawson headed it back across goal, you know, unhindered at that point by Inana. But then there's that coming together as he saw it between two players who neither got to the ball. But clearly Inana, you know, jumps into the Wolves player and it should have been intervened upon. So when we get those clear errors that happen in the game and we don't rectify those, they make a lot of noise, of course. And, you know, I can sit here and say, you know, we rectify a lot, a lot more than we don't. But they're not the ones that make noise, I understand that. So when we get something like Monday night, it does create a bit of damage to the positive direction that we think we're taking overall. You know, we've seen improvements in the last few months in the way we use VAR, but situations like that obviously don't help. I suppose ultimately you can have VAR forever and it will correct most things in the right manner and it will lead to fairer decisions overall. But it still comes down to human decisions, doesn't it? Therefore, you know, what is a clear and obvious mistake to one referee might not be quite so much to another. And it's never going to be perfect, I suppose. No, that's really valid that, Gary, because, you know, our sport is one which does throw up a lot of situations that split opinion. I mean, you know, there's loads of talk about situations, whether they should or should not have been a penalty. And I've been doing some club visits in the pre-season. So I went to see Luton, I went to see Sheffield United, obviously new to the Premier League, new to VAR, at least in Luton's case, not having had it before, having not been in the Premier League before. And I showed the players a situation, a penalty from a game at Nottingham Forest last year. And we knew it was one that would split opinion. It was kind of like one of those that, like, you know, we thought would go 50-50 and it absolutely did. 50% of the players said that's a penalty and 50% said it wasn't. So my challenge is trying to work out how to use... But surely, Howard, if it's 50-50, you go, if it's a decision like that, that you think is going to be 50-50, you stick with the referee's decision on the pitch, don't you? Absolutely. Yeah, absolutely. That's absolutely our philosophy because, you know, if, imagine the penalty is given and you're one of the 50% that thinks it's a good decision, and then VAR goes to the screen and overturns it, you're pleasing 50% of the people who didn't think it was a penalty. But if you thought it was, then you think VAR is nonsensical in that situation. And the following week, it's probably the other 50% that feel that way. So within three, four weeks, you know, you've kind of like disenfranchised everybody about VAR. We think if we can set expectations around us only intervening when something is clearly wrong, and the skill that we've got to have as VARs is recognising when something is clearly wrong. I mean, Alan, you and I have spoken about this, about talking about clangers, only dealing with clangers. Monday night was a clanger, by the way. So even working to that threshold, we can still get it wrong because we're working with human beings who are in a pressured situation, looking at something, knowing that they can't take forever to make a decision. And sometimes they just overthink it. And they're trying to be in line with what we're trying to do here, not overly interfering. But sometimes they just miss the mark like everybody does. We get it right way more than we get it wrong. But of course, I know that an error like Monday is really impactful. You know, that's why I want to get to Gary Neal fairly quickly and say, Gary, that's not our standard. We've got to do better than that. In that situation, it should have been a pen. And the officials aren't working this weekend. So we understand there's a need for accountability because our errors impact somebody else. When we make a mistake, it impacts, in that case, Wolves. If you're the Wolves' goalkeeper, you make an error, you're impacting your own team. But our mistakes impact other people. So there's an accountability that we have to show as well, while also keeping the officials confident and feeling like they're able to make decisions and not being afraid to do so by overthinking. Howard, just a couple of things from that. I'm a huge admirer of you coming out and having the transparency because we've never had that before. And I think we all appreciate and admire that. But two things from the other evening is I've read it this week that as a few people have said now, because the VAR official was less senior than the referee on the pitch, do you think that sometimes comes into their head that he's slightly afraid to overrule the bigger-name referee or the more experienced referee? And secondly, do you ever foresee the future and think that there is a space for ex-footballers to come in and possibly advise a VAR referee who sat in the hub? Yeah. So on the first point about the dynamic between the on-field official and the VAR, I think that's a valid point. I think that, and particularly when we first started this VAR sort of journey, I was out in Major League Soccer putting the program in there. So similar sort of challenges. We faced situations where less senior officials sitting in the VAR chair were kind of reticent to call out an error of a senior colleague who'd been around for a lot longer and was usually refereeing at a higher level. I think that's become less prevalent as we've seen who's good at doing VAR. Some of the less experienced officials are really good at doing VAR and the on-field officials know that. So we've got to a stage now where somebody like Michael Salisbury, who was the VAR on Monday, that was quite an uncharacteristic error by Michael because we've seen time and again him do really well. In fact, some of the things we've played out in the past few months have included Michael. Was he not the same official at Spurs Brighton last season? Yeah, he was. He missed the penalty by the Spurs lad on Matoma. So he's not perfect, but we're using him a lot because we do trust in him. We do believe in him. Everybody's going to make a mistake and obviously if he continues making them, there's an issue, but he's made a couple, but that's outweighed by the good interventions that he's had. And people do generally know that he's good at what he does. So our job is to pick the best VARs and try to pair them off with the officials who they have a good relationship with. So it's not a factor we need to minimise that as much as possible. In terms of ex-players, when I first came into this role in December, I did quite a few interviews. You do the media rounds and I actually mentioned about the fact that I find it quite incredible that we don't have any ex-players in our group of officials or any players who have played at a professional level, let's say, National League or above. I think clearly that tells me that refereeing is not something that players and you guys can speak for yourselves, but find appealing. It's not something you'd fancy doing, but I'm sure there's a way we can change that. And I think we'd really benefit from having some players coming into our ranks. So it's something we're trying to push. It's on us to do that, to make the pathway shorter, to make referees seem more appealing, to find a way of getting to players. Maybe you'll get injured at 23, 24 or come into their retirement age at 34, 35. Not so much ex-players in terms of being referees. I'm talking about ex-players to be sitting in the VAR hub to actually just lend their opinion rather than you clearing the pathway for them to be referees. To just sit and lend their experience in the VAR hub and sit with the referees. Yeah. We've already started taking on board expertise from the playing side of the game. So our coaching director, for example, is Wayne Allison, who played many times in the football league. So obviously he brings all of his experience. We've also got expertise from outside of our sport. We've got people working with us in the VAR space from Ruby League. In terms of getting the footballers into the VAR hub on a match day to actually give in-game advice or guidance or to steer decisions, that's not possible at the moment. The only people who can actually make the decisions are the VAR and the AVAR. Their match officials make decisions. We don't have anybody else looking over their shoulder telling them what to do, what not to do. We don't think that's appropriate. We want the officials to be on the field making decisions and also in the VAR hub as well. If we had somebody else influencing that decision, that would be inappropriate, we feel, and FIFA feel the same way. I'd like to have ex-players though assisting us in our training more and more. So expanding that group of experts that are coming in. We've got some football insights experts that have joined our organisation recently. Chris Kawami has just joined our organisation, for example, as one of those people. We consult a lot with the PFA and the LMA to get some insights from that part of the game, the most important part of the game. If we could have players, ex-players as VARs, trained as VARs, I would welcome that as an opportunity to look into. At the moment, we're not allowed to do that. They have to be current or former top referees. So the only way we can get them into the chair is get them onto the field as refs and then get them into the VAR space and let's see how they would do. But at the moment, we're restricted to only being able to use refs in that particular role. I just want good people who are able to know the game, understand the game, able to recognise clear errors consistently, communicate quickly, work as a team in that space. It's a pressurised environment. It's not just like watching TV at home. There's an awful lot that goes into following the process. Make sure you don't miss something. A number of times, you'll see a penalty appeal and the VAR starts looking at that while the game continues live and then they form an opinion that they need to intervene. But you've got to remember to check the attacking phase of play because there could be an offside in the buildup. And if you forget to do that, then there's a big problem if there was an offside and you've given a penalty. So there's loads of process that we have to go through. But expanding that out to people who've got real lived experience of playing the game, I think, would be, in my opinion, really potentially beneficial if we can get people in through whatever means, then I'd welcome a chance to look at that. My question would be in terms of you mentioned that the pressurised situations, but early when VAR started, everyone was saying it was taking too long, but would you rather not take a little bit longer and get the decision right? You're not in the crowd where the crowd are looking when the referee goes to the screen and it can have an effect on how he's feeling in that moment, say you're away at Old Trafford or Man City or any of the big clubs, but you said you're in a room, would you rather not just take a little bit more time and get the decision right rather than rushing it and getting it wrong? 100%, Micah. I would never want to sacrifice accuracy for the sake of speed. If we can get both, then we're in the ideal world. If we're not taking too long, then we can be accurate. I would always say to the guys at work in the VAR hub, do the due diligence that you need to do. You can't take shortcuts. You've got to do it properly. You've got to look at the angles that you need to look at. I don't want them looking at the same angle seven, eight times. That's not something that's clearly wrong if they're having to do that. They might need to look at seven different angles once or twice because it might be the seventh angle that shows you the very clear image that you guys will show on match of the day because you've got people who are looking for that angle. We have to find that angle in the moment before it's too late, before the game's restarted. Sometimes they need to do that. One of the things that I think is really beneficial of us going out and showing how the process works is that people understand the camera angles that we've got to look at. They understand why it might take a bit of time, why the referee stood on the field with a finger to the rear, not allowing the restart to happen. We want to be as least interfering as we can be. I want as many goals that are scored to be allowed to stand so people can celebrate knowing that there's only a really small chance of that goal being taken away. If it's allowed to stand, it'll be a good goal. The team that's conceded know it's a fair goal. We want to be really accurate 100% of the time if that's possible. That's the ambition, but also do it in an efficient way, but never sacrifice the accuracy for the speed. By the way, just to dispel another myth as well, when the referee goes to the screen, they can absolutely keep their decision if they want to. Sometimes the VAR gets it wrong. They're sitting in this somewhat sterile environment watching a screen from some distance away from the smell and the feel and the atmosphere of the game. Therefore, they might recommend a review for the referee to go over. The referee might look at it and say, honestly, I don't know what you're seeing, but there's no expectation based on my feeling of what I saw at the time, the feeling I'm getting from the players and what I'm seeing now to change that decision. Thanks a lot for recommending the review, but I'm going to keep my call. Now, it shouldn't happen too often if the VARs are good at recognizing clear errors because normally you'd go over and say, yep, that is a clear error. I agree and I'm going to change it. They are absolutely entitled to keep their decision if they feel that's the right thing to do. In terms of the fans, Howard, there's a feeling around the country that sometimes the big clubs, and I think Micah alluded to it slightly, sometimes the big clubs seem to get their way. Obviously Manchester United on Monday. I presume you'd absolutely deny there's any truth in that, but that's the question that fans would expect me to ask. Yeah. There's that perception. I hear it from fans I speak to, I hear it on radio shows that I listen to as I'm driving around and also on podcasts like this, but also when I speak to clubs, I sometimes get that level that is from clubs that kind of sit outside the traditional top six. Usually what I do, I end up giving a balanced view with the clubs that I'm visiting to show things that have gone for and against. Honestly speaking, things generally speaking, kind of even out in terms of the things that go for and against. I've seen some situations go for teams that would be considered the bigger ones and we saw that on Monday night, but equally I've seen ones go in the favour of teams. I remember we got some criticism last year for, there was a really tough weekend. You remember the one in February and we had three situations in one weekend. One was the Crystal Palace Brighton situation where the lines weren't placed in the right place due to some process errors and we're trying to ensure that the process is absolutely embedded with our officials through the increased training. The same day Brentford scored against Arsenal, Norgard was offside and there was a bit of a complicated check just before that. We were trying to get some lines placed on a possible interfering with the opponent and then that put pressure on the VAR, sped up through the rest of the attacking phase and missed Norgard coming back from an offside position. Then also the same day, Chelsea felt they should have had a penalty against West Ham. I think it was Suchek and went down to his left to try to block a shot with his knee and it ended up saving it with his hand. It was a good save. That was two situations that went against two of what we would consider the biggest six, if you like, in Chelsea and Arsenal. The stats don't always bear out the perception, but I know the perception exists. Again, one of my biggest challenges is to try to change the way that things are perceived, I think. The more that I can give real information that I think is insightful and interesting, then the better because I think that shows the real picture rather than just what people perceive. Howard, I know that you yourself or your organisation can't change the laws. You're guided by IFAB. That's correct in what I'm saying, yes? Yeah, that's right. How would you personally like to deliver the handball law? Because I personally feel that's one of the biggest issues in our game and I think it's most confusing in our game and I think that's where there's a lot of inconsistency in our game and that's what angers players, fans, managers, coaches. How would you personally like to see the handball law? How would you like to see it delivered? It's a really good question and you saw my reaction when you asked the question. Handball is the most subjective area, the area where we struggle to get the most consistency. It used to be all right, Howard. It used to be okay and back in the day it used to use a bit of common sense and you could tell there was an element of whether it's deliberate or not, but now it's got so complex, hasn't it? Yeah, and we've seen more changes in this part of the law than anywhere else, Gary. Do you know, I think that's the answer. Just go back to allowing the referee to determine if something is a deliberate handball. The difficulty is that obviously in a lot of your handball situations do we see a player moving their hand towards the ball? In fact, it happens rarely, doesn't it? How many times the defenders truly deliberately handle the ball in the penalty area? Most times it's either something they've kind of like they've just flapped it ahead and their arms up and bizarrely they flick it away with their hand under pressure from an opponent or they go to block a ball, but they put their arms out in a position which kind of does increase their body size and they get an advantage from that because the position of the arm blocks the shot. Even if they were trying to do it with their chest or their leg, they get this advantage from the arms being away from the body. So they're not going into that challenge thinking, I'm going to try and block this with my arm. You know, the few exceptions would be like the Suarez one in the 2010 World Cup, he flicks over the bar. They're few and far between. They're generally trying to get their arms out of the way. Yeah, exactly. So I think that's why we've got in the situation where we are. The way that the law is written is try to accommodate those situations where players don't mean to do it, but they do and they get an advantage from doing it. But it's hard. It's hard to judge because what's natural and what's not natural depends on so many different variables, doesn't it? And therefore, I think probably the more kind of extreme the arm positions are, the more credible a penalty decision would be. I don't think we can only say we'll penalize only when players deliberately move their hands to the ball because that would leave a lot of situations where you guys, I imagine, would say, yeah, that has to be a penalty. Look at the arm position. It's in a really unnatural place. He's got a big advantage from that. So I think moving a little bit away from where we've been recently around too many handball penalties being given, we've tried to ease back a little bit in that respect, allowing the referee to make a judgment as to whether the arm position is really totally unjustified. But I think we're better being in a place where we only penalize when it is totally unjustified. And if it's in the margins, give the benefit of the doubt to the defender unless you see that movement. What I wouldn't want, and I have heard it mentioned, what I wouldn't want is a situation where we penalize every contact with the arm simply because I just think that players would start to just drive the ball towards players arms. I just think that it would be the target rather than the goal. It's probably easier to play as arm than it is to at the back of the net. So let's drive our shot towards or our cross towards the defender. And then it'd be a game of dodgeball, wouldn't it? Howard, I just want to finish on a point that I think is very important. I think I've experienced a lot of football inside the stadium with VAR and from a fan's perspective, you do not know what is going on. All you see is a review of so-and-so and you sit there for two minutes and you wait a decision. When do you think it will come that will, I know it started in the Women's World Cup, we've started that slight explanation of a decision at the end, but we need to hear the conversation that goes on between the referee and the VAR. Like you get in other sports, cricket, rugby, for example, is that going to come? Because at the moment, I think it's not fair on the fans, particularly in the stadium. Yeah, and they're the most important fans of all going out there with respect to the TV audience, the ones who are in the stadium, creating the atmosphere, the ones that you played in front of and I officiated in front of that give you that great feeling when you walk out at five to three. Yeah, we need to be better in that respect. And it's not been easy enough to crack a think and trying to work out how to communicate because what's happening at the minute is not enough. We need to do more in stadium. So I think that what we're seeing down in Australia, New Zealand will expand into some domestic leagues as early as the next few weeks. I heard actually only a few days ago that it's not only when they go to the screen that they can make the announcement, they're actually now enabled towards the back end of the tournament, they allow the officials to speak as well when a check is happening before you actually go to the screen. That's when sometimes you're still there with the finger to the ear to say, you know, we are checking for a possible act of violent conduct by number six or a possible offside by number 10 or whatever. So I think that's useful as well. I think that's the direction that most leagues will take. We'll have a conversation with the Premier League and any other leagues that take VAR on. I think the Women's Super League might be taking the VAR system on board at some point soon and the Football League are looking closely at it. The other aspect is the TV broadcaster. So when I was in MLS, we opened up the broadcast, the audio to broadcast for a few games. We were told not to do that by FIFA until approval had been given. So we set up a working group and I'm still on this working group that's looking at how we can do that better because we've got absolutely nothing to hide. We've played it out to the TV audience on shows, on Sky and on other channels as well. And we've also done it to the broadcasters behind the scenes. I know some of you guys have been on those calls where we've played the audio to you so you can hear what's been said. So big fans of opening up as much information as possible. An example of that is we've started now running the clock in the stadium beyond 45 and 90 minutes, which is, I think we're the first league or leagues in the world to do that. I made a phone call and said, look, this is nonsensical. We're holding up seven minutes on the board. Fans don't know how long beyond 90 minutes has gone. The whistling from two or three minutes in, players are asking how long's left. Just show people. Let's treat people in the way they deserve to be treated in terms of the information sharing so they can see that we've only played five minutes. We've got another two to go. People understand there's going to be another minute on top of that if we've had a goal or a substitution. So let's just do things right. Let's open up the information and let's bring this game kicking and screaming into the 21st century. Well, Howard, thank you very much for talking to us. This is an exact example of how things can help towards people's understanding of what VAR is and how referees and how difficult it is and communication, I think, is really important. So thank you so much for your time. Alan and Michael as well, thank you. And we'll say goodbye to everyone until the next time. Thanks very much, Howard. Really appreciate it. Thanks, guys. Great to see you. Cheers, Howard. Goodbye. Bye.

segments.text: Hello and welcome to the Rest is Football with me, Garel Inneke. I'm joined of course
by Alan Shearer and Micah Richards. We've got a special episode for you today that's
a little bit different from those that we've done before. That's because we've got a certain
guest joining us a little later on. This is something we're going to look to do throughout
the season on the Rest is Football. Whenever there's a big topical talking point going
on within the sport, we'll get someone on to help us look into them in a bit more detail
and give their expert insight. Following the opening weekend of the Premier League, it
was, well, the same old story, wasn't it really, with the VAR dominating the headlines once
I'm pleased to say that Howard Webb, the PGMOL's Chief Refereeing Officer, is joining us later
in the show to help us reflect on some of those decisions and understand what is going
on this season. Before we get Howard on though, I want to look back at some of the major talking
points and the big story of the week of course is that the Lionesses are in the World Cup
final. How about that? What an achievement. They played so well in that game against Australia,
didn't they?
We had a conversation about their form and gradually it's got better and better and better.
Obviously the big conundrum is Lauren James. She got suspended for two games. Now she's
available for the final. But Ella Toon in that position, she was outstanding. She took
a finish excellently well. The way she just bent it. When the ball comes to you like that,
you lot are a better player to talk about it than me. But there's only one way you could
hit it to make it go in the top. You sort of like brush across the ball and it was an
outstanding finish. The three centre halves, Greenwood, Bright and Carter have been exceptional
this tournament as well. And just a real good feel good factor around the team. At times,
you're worrying how they're going to set up. But Serena Vigman, she always has a way. And just
getting to the final is a massive achievement. So well done the Lionesses.
Are you bringing Lauren James back in?
That's a conundrum. I mean, it's one of those games where the final in any final is always tense.
And the game is going to be open in the second half. So keep it tight and then bring on Lauren
James to get the winner or change the game. So I would keep the winning team from the semi-final.
What would you lot do?
I was playing in a Pro-Am with Lee Westwood. There's a big tournament going on at my local
course, Close House, the International Series England and the Asian Tour. And it's a really
good feeling. I was lucky enough to play in the Pro-Am there on Wednesday. Whilst the game was
going on, I said to the tournament director on the first tee, I said, I know you're not meant
to have phones on the course, but it cannot stop me having a phone today with England in the
semi-final. It was my excuse for being shit anyway, because I kept checking my phone.
And Alan, I have to say, it's great that the two are in a final.
Yeah, it's just, it's magnificent. And I mean, when you're looking at the viewing figures
for people watching on television, again, they've captured the nation, the country,
and everyone's supporting them. It's great to see. And what a morning Sunday is going to be,
isn't it? Eleven o'clock kickoff here in England. And wow, what an opportunity again for them.
It's just magnificent.
Yeah. Spain, of course, in the final. It's a horrible question to ask. Are they going to do it?
We've got to back them. We've backed them all the way, haven't we? And Mike is right. We've said
that. We've mentioned about form and just getting through the tournament stage by stage,
and they've been able to do that and the performances have picked up. So judging by that,
they're going to get better again in the final. And of course, they're going to do it.
I'll just say a couple of things. I mean, A, the finishing was superb, wasn't it? All three goals
were exceptional. But a word for the goalkeeper, because they often, in the past few years,
the goalkeepers in the women's game have got a lot of stick. But I think the goalkeeping
in this tournament has showed how much they've improved. And Mary Earps, I mean, she's a hell
of a keeper, isn't she? Outstanding again. I've worked with her in doing some TV work and she's,
I think what makes her so good is her own self-belief. She's had a tough run and she
wasn't always number one for England. It's only because one of the goalkeepers got injured and
she took a chance and it's a confident self-belief that just makes her believe how good she is. And
she performs well. She's good with her feet. She makes some outstanding saves. And you know what
it is? She's calm under pressure. That's what I love about her. Every time someone goes through,
she just does a job. She's not after the limelight. She just does her job. So yeah, she's been great.
You'd back her in a penalty shootout as well, wouldn't you?
Indeed, I would, Alan. Well, they've already won one of those.
You mentioned calmness there and I think that's probably the thing that comes out for me the most
of this particular team. They do seem to have a calm. They don't get overexcited. They don't
seem to get too nervous. They don't over-celebrate perhaps when they score and they don't seem to be
affected when things go against them a little bit in the game. Yeah, but that comes from the manager,
doesn't it, Gary? I think that started long before the tournament because as we know that with the
issues through injuries that they had, she never panicked, did she? It was just like, yep, we've
got to accept it. We've got to take it. It's happened. We just got to move on. And I think
that all comes from the manager. Well, let's all wish them all the very best in the final.
It's been a long time since England won a football World Cup. It would be truly special, but whatever
happens, they've definitely done us proud in this tournament. One other issue that's happened in
midweek since we last spoke is that Manchester City, Mica, have won another trophy, the Supercop.
Yeah, I mean, watching Manchester City now, they're obviously a great team, but Kevin de Bruyne
gets a big injury. Gunderwands left. And it seems to me like they're just not, they're not in a groove.
It's early stages. Manchester City always take a little bit time to get going. They have all that
possession, but it just feels like to me that something is missing at this moment in time.
Haaland was making so many runs in this game against Seville. Seville was a very good team,
very compact, know how to defend. But there seems like there's a link between the midfield and the
tack that is missing. I was so happy for Cole Palmer. He scored in the Community Shield and
he gets another goal. And it was strange that the interview after with Pep, he's basically saying
he's not going on loan. He's either for sale or he's going to be with the squad, which I thought was
interesting. They've been linked with Packatar and I really do like him, but he's not got to the
heights I thought he would before Manchester City was interested. So it's going to be intriguing to
see how the season pans out in terms of creativity. Cole Palmer, I mean, it's a hell of a start for
the season for him. So do you think he can grab a place in that team, Haaland? He can get a place
in it, but there's no way he's going to replicate what Kevin de Bruyne can do. I mean, and it would
be unfair of us to even suggest that because we've been going on and on and rightly so about
Kevin de Bruyne and how brilliant he is and one of the best players in the world and how much
we as forwards would like to be on the end of his passes. So it wouldn't be fair of us to say he's
going to come in and do what he can do, but there's no doubt about it. He brings a certain and a
different talent to that team and he's had a great start to the season. Mike had just said with his
goal a couple of weeks ago, his goal again on Wednesday evening. Yeah, he's an exceptional
player, but there's no way he's filling de Bruyne's boots. Since we last spoke, of course,
the other side in Manchester have been in action. They played Wolves on Monday night. Now,
we all thought Wolves had struggled this season. I actually had them in my bottom three, but I
thought they played so well in that game. I was thinking about changing my mind. The only thing
that worries you about Wolves is they couldn't finish off a bag of crisps, could they? Really?
They had so many chances in that game, but boy did they play well. Yeah, and when you consider
the small amount of time that Gary Neal has had to work with his team, I thought they were really
well organised. They're obviously all on the same page, but yeah, their big problem last season,
scoring goals and again the other night, it looks as if that's going to be the same thing again.
They created so much. They did so well and of course they were robbed with a decision,
which I'm sure we're going to get on to, but overall in general, I thought a lot of their
player was excellent. Matthias Cunha was, his performance was extraordinary. He just couldn't
finish it off, but that aside, he caused havoc in United's midfield in particular.
Really? Well, I only seen the first half because you've probably seen this week,
I've been at Old Trafford taking penalties. We're getting on to that. Don't you worry by the way.
We're getting on to that. I can tell you my record is still zero goals at Old Trafford.
We know what your record is. It's fucking useless.
Micah, is it true that you're just a shit Gary Neal shit?
We heard the crowd singing. Was it embarrassing or was it fun?
No, it was absolutely amazing. We did a little bit of training beforehand.
It didn't look like it.
Explain to people first, Micah, explain to people first what you were doing and why on earth you
were taking penalties at Old Trafford. Well, I didn't know we was allowed to promote
different people on there, so I was sort of leaving that out, but it was for League of the
Roam. That's fine. You can promote what you want on here. It's how we're doing.
So we're sure we can do what we want, Micah. Wonderful. I feel free.
Free. So, okay, let's go back to the beginning. One of the regulars on League of the Roam.
As you know, League of the Roam is a fun sports program. So someone came up with the idea.
Don't be jealous, Alan. Don't be jealous. So someone came up with the idea of going to Old
Trafford, me being Manchester City and Jamie Redknapp being obviously Liverpool, taking penalties
at half time. So before that, we had three hours training at the cliff. And for those who don't
know, it's old Man United training ground. So much history there. Brilliant. So in training,
I was slotting them left, right, dink, whatnot. Okay. We arrive at Old Trafford. And you know
what it's like at Old Trafford? You get a certain part of love. The fans are nice and whatnot.
And you just get them ones who are just looking at you like, what the fuck are you doing here?
So we go out there, we get changed. We're walking down and we're getting so much abuse. What are you
doing? What is this fucking shit? What has Old Trafford become now? It's an absolute joke.
So the aim is we get three penalties each and we have to score basically the most. And whoever
loses has to wear a Man United shirt. So I go up, I go first, don't I? So I'm going down the touch
line and I'm getting abused. I'm getting abused. All sorts. But then the fans started quite enjoying
it. So giving me a bit, but like clapping me and all that. And then I got that thing, you lot,
see we've talked about my penalty before and I thought to myself, just relax, just relax.
What did I do with the first one? I hit the post. Right side of the keeper, the second one,
the keeper saves to the keeper's left. Please tell me you got the third one in.
And the third one, he saved us. Micah, I wouldn't be too worried about the penalty,
Mrs. I'd be more worried about that fucking tight top you had on.
It was tight, wasn't it? I thought it was a spray on it was that tight.
So I presume that you had to wear the Manchester United top then because surely, surely he scored
one, didn't he Red Knapp? Red Knapp scored two and he shanked one. He had to do it, didn't he? Look
at me, I'm JB Red Knapp, absolutely melt. It must have been quite embarrassing having to
work, not only having not scored one, but also having to put a United top on. Must have been hard.
It was horrible. And it's not the first time I've done that as well. Shocking. But never again. I'm
never doing anything like that again. I think we all tipped Manchester United to be in the top four.
Did it put you off? Because they were, I mean, I know they got three points, Alan, but I mean,
and it's so early in the season, but they looked, I mean, they looked very vulnerable,
particularly midfield. They were overrun a bit. Yeah, I tend to wait for half a dozen games to
be gone before I start and alter or change my predictions or opinions of what's going to happen.
But yeah, it looked as if they've got a lot of work to do, particularly in the midfield area,
because they were outplayed, out-thought, out-thought. And they looked second best in
the midfield area. So that would be a bit of a concern for me, for Man United.
And of course, there was that extraordinary decision at the end. And that's the reason that,
well, one of the reasons, because we want to talk about perhaps the new laws a little bit, but more
about how VAR will work. And after the break, we'll talk to Howard Webb about that. So
let's take a breather.
Welcome back to the Rest is Football with me, Garry Lineker,
Micah Richards and Alan Shearer. And I'm delighted to say we're joined by Howard Webb,
who is obviously in charge of all things VAR these days and referees. And Howard,
it's been an interesting opening weekend for you. But before we come to discussing those things,
I think we should address the elephant in the room, because the certain Alan Shearer
still blames you for losing him his job.
Explain yourself, please, Howard.
Alan, it's taken 10 years, but obviously people are talking about acknowledging errors at the
moment. And I do have to acknowledge that error. I blame Kevin Nolan.
What happened, Howard?
It was Newcastle Fulham. By the way, I'm not totally to blame. I only refereed one of those
games that you were in charge for. But yeah, Kevin had been standing on the toes of Mark
Schwarzer at corners. And I had a word with Kevin, and this corner was awarded. And I saw him do it
again. So I stopped it. You see referees blowing the whistle, going in, having a word and what
have you. So I did that. And I said, look, don't do it. Don't stand on his toes. Anyway,
so as the corners coming in, he moves towards Schwarzer. I just reacted too quickly and blew.
And he kind of just stopped short of doing it. And Mark Viduka slammed this shot into the top
corner, like majestically, as I'm blowing the whistle thinking, oh my goodness, I've blown too
soon. And no VAR, no opportunity to change it. And I spent the rest of the day thinking, I hope
Newcastle come back into this game. And they didn't. And I ended up having to send a player
off for a professional foul as well, a dog's hole thing. And Newcastle lost. And then I think
you went to Villa on the last day, Alan, needing a win or a point. I can't remember. And you didn't
obviously get it. And I remember I was down at West Ham on the same day, thinking, coming off
the field, thinking, I hope Newcastle have got something out of the game because otherwise that
is going to be, you know, that's going to be pretty significant, that decision to disallow that goal.
Do you forgive him, Alan?
Well, we did get relegated. And that goal did cost us a point. And we only got relegated by a point.
So, but don't worry, Howard, I don't hold fucking grudges. You're all right.
Well, I think we could swear.
You can swear. You can do what you want on it.
We'll do what we want. It's a podcast.
You have to forgive him. Thanks for coming on anyway. Thank you.
Yeah, very much so. Howard, I suppose as it's time for kind of admitting mistakes,
you did so with one at the weekend. Well, it's actually Monday night, wasn't it? Manchester
United was probably the biggest, most controversial decision at the weekend. You recognised that was a
mistake. Yeah, yeah, we did. Obviously, like any club going into a new season, we want to start
well, we want to start strong. And, you know, we've obviously done a lot of prep work in the
pre-season and we're actually cranking up our VAR training more than ever before as well. So we were
actually in the VAR hub on Friday, going through quite a few situations and just trying to drive
that consistency. And we have a philosophy about how we use VAR. I think you're familiar with it.
It's around VAR not re-refereeing the game, but sitting there to protect against those clear
errors. And we saw a clear error on Monday night, late in the game. I was actually at the game and
it looked a penalty, honestly speaking, from where I was sitting in the stand. And I expected when
it wasn't given, the referee to go to the screen and have a look at it and then give the penalty.
And when that didn't happen, obviously it was really disappointing. The VAR looked at it,
saw that neither the goalkeeper or the Wolves player made contact with the ball.
Dawson headed it back across goal, you know, unhindered at that point by Inana. But then
there's that coming together as he saw it between two players who neither got to the ball. But clearly
Inana, you know, jumps into the Wolves player and it should have been intervened upon. So when we get
those clear errors that happen in the game and we don't rectify those, they make a lot of noise,
of course. And, you know, I can sit here and say, you know, we rectify a lot, a lot more than we
don't. But they're not the ones that make noise, I understand that. So when we get something like
Monday night, it does create a bit of damage to the positive direction that we think we're taking
overall. You know, we've seen improvements in the last few months in the way we use VAR, but
situations like that obviously don't help. I suppose ultimately you can have VAR forever and
it will correct most things in the right manner and it will lead to fairer decisions overall.
But it still comes down to human decisions, doesn't it? Therefore, you know, what is a clear
and obvious mistake to one referee might not be quite so much to another. And it's never going
to be perfect, I suppose. No, that's really valid that, Gary, because, you know, our sport is one
which does throw up a lot of situations that split opinion. I mean, you know, there's loads of
talk about situations, whether they should or should not have been a penalty. And I've been
doing some club visits in the pre-season. So I went to see Luton, I went to see Sheffield United,
obviously new to the Premier League, new to VAR, at least in Luton's case, not having had it before,
having not been in the Premier League before. And I showed the players a situation, a penalty from
a game at Nottingham Forest last year. And we knew it was one that would split opinion. It was
kind of like one of those that, like, you know, we thought would go 50-50 and it absolutely did.
50% of the players said that's a penalty and 50% said it wasn't. So my challenge is trying to
work out how to use... But surely, Howard, if it's 50-50, you go, if it's a decision like that,
that you think is going to be 50-50, you stick with the referee's decision on the pitch, don't you?
Absolutely. Yeah, absolutely. That's absolutely our philosophy because, you know, if, imagine the
penalty is given and you're one of the 50% that thinks it's a good decision, and then VAR goes to
the screen and overturns it, you're pleasing 50% of the people who didn't think it was a penalty.
But if you thought it was, then you think VAR is nonsensical in that situation. And the following
week, it's probably the other 50% that feel that way. So within three, four weeks, you know, you've
kind of like disenfranchised everybody about VAR. We think if we can set expectations around us only
intervening when something is clearly wrong, and the skill that we've got to have as VARs is
recognising when something is clearly wrong. I mean, Alan, you and I have spoken about this,
about talking about clangers, only dealing with clangers. Monday night was a clanger, by the way.
So even working to that threshold, we can still get it wrong because we're working with human
beings who are in a pressured situation, looking at something, knowing that they can't take forever
to make a decision. And sometimes they just overthink it. And they're trying to be in line
with what we're trying to do here, not overly interfering. But sometimes they just miss the
mark like everybody does. We get it right way more than we get it wrong. But of course, I know
that an error like Monday is really impactful. You know, that's why I want to get to Gary Neal
fairly quickly and say, Gary, that's not our standard. We've got to do better than that.
In that situation, it should have been a pen. And the officials aren't working this weekend. So we
understand there's a need for accountability because our errors impact somebody else. When
we make a mistake, it impacts, in that case, Wolves. If you're the Wolves' goalkeeper, you make an
error, you're impacting your own team. But our mistakes impact other people. So there's an
accountability that we have to show as well, while also keeping the officials confident and
feeling like they're able to make decisions and not being afraid to do so by overthinking.
Howard, just a couple of things from that. I'm a huge admirer of you coming out and having the
transparency because we've never had that before. And I think we all appreciate and admire that.
But two things from the other evening is I've read it this week that as a few people have said now,
because the VAR official was less senior than the referee on the pitch, do you think that sometimes
comes into their head that he's slightly afraid to overrule the bigger-name referee or the more
experienced referee? And secondly, do you ever foresee the future and think that there is a space
for ex-footballers to come in and possibly advise a VAR referee who sat in the hub?
Yeah. So on the first point about the dynamic between the on-field official and the VAR,
I think that's a valid point. I think that, and particularly when we first started this VAR
sort of journey, I was out in Major League Soccer putting the program in there. So similar sort of
challenges. We faced situations where less senior officials sitting in the VAR chair were kind of
reticent to call out an error of a senior colleague who'd been around for a lot longer and was
usually refereeing at a higher level. I think that's become less prevalent as we've seen who's
good at doing VAR. Some of the less experienced officials are really good at doing VAR and the
on-field officials know that. So we've got to a stage now where somebody like Michael Salisbury,
who was the VAR on Monday, that was quite an uncharacteristic error by Michael because
we've seen time and again him do really well. In fact, some of the things we've played out in
the past few months have included Michael. Was he not the same official at Spurs Brighton last season?
Yeah, he was. He missed the penalty by the Spurs lad on Matoma. So he's not perfect,
but we're using him a lot because we do trust in him. We do believe in him. Everybody's going
to make a mistake and obviously if he continues making them, there's an issue, but he's made a
couple, but that's outweighed by the good interventions that he's had. And people do
generally know that he's good at what he does. So our job is to pick the best VARs and try to
pair them off with the officials who they have a good relationship with. So it's not a factor
we need to minimise that as much as possible. In terms of ex-players, when I first came into
this role in December, I did quite a few interviews. You do the media rounds and I actually
mentioned about the fact that I find it quite incredible that we don't have any ex-players in
our group of officials or any players who have played at a professional level, let's say,
National League or above. I think clearly that tells me that refereeing is not something that
players and you guys can speak for yourselves, but find appealing. It's not something you'd
fancy doing, but I'm sure there's a way we can change that. And I think we'd really benefit from
having some players coming into our ranks. So it's something we're trying to push. It's on
us to do that, to make the pathway shorter, to make referees seem more appealing, to find a way
of getting to players. Maybe you'll get injured at 23, 24 or come into their retirement age at 34, 35.
Not so much ex-players in terms of being referees. I'm talking about ex-players to be sitting in the
VAR hub to actually just lend their opinion rather than you clearing the pathway for them to be
referees. To just sit and lend their experience in the VAR hub and sit with the referees.
Yeah. We've already started taking on board expertise from the playing side of the game.
So our coaching director, for example, is Wayne Allison, who played many times in the football
league. So obviously he brings all of his experience. We've also got expertise from
outside of our sport. We've got people working with us in the VAR space from Ruby League.
In terms of getting the footballers into the VAR hub on a match day to actually give in-game advice
or guidance or to steer decisions, that's not possible at the moment. The only people who can
actually make the decisions are the VAR and the AVAR. Their match officials make decisions. We
don't have anybody else looking over their shoulder telling them what to do, what not to do. We
don't think that's appropriate. We want the officials to be on the field making decisions and
also in the VAR hub as well. If we had somebody else influencing that decision, that would be
inappropriate, we feel, and FIFA feel the same way. I'd like to have ex-players though assisting
us in our training more and more. So expanding that group of experts that are coming in. We've
got some football insights experts that have joined our organisation recently. Chris Kawami
has just joined our organisation, for example, as one of those people. We consult a lot with the
PFA and the LMA to get some insights from that part of the game, the most important part of the
game. If we could have players, ex-players as VARs, trained as VARs, I would welcome that as an
opportunity to look into. At the moment, we're not allowed to do that. They have to be current or
former top referees. So the only way we can get them into the chair is get them onto the field as
refs and then get them into the VAR space and let's see how they would do. But at the moment,
we're restricted to only being able to use refs in that particular role. I just want good people
who are able to know the game, understand the game, able to recognise clear errors consistently,
communicate quickly, work as a team in that space. It's a pressurised environment. It's not just like
watching TV at home. There's an awful lot that goes into following the process. Make sure you
don't miss something. A number of times, you'll see a penalty appeal and the VAR starts looking
at that while the game continues live and then they form an opinion that they need to intervene.
But you've got to remember to check the attacking phase of play because there could be an offside
in the buildup. And if you forget to do that, then there's a big problem if there was an offside and
you've given a penalty. So there's loads of process that we have to go through. But expanding that
out to people who've got real lived experience of playing the game, I think, would be,
in my opinion, really potentially beneficial if we can get people in through whatever means,
then I'd welcome a chance to look at that. My question would be in terms of you mentioned
that the pressurised situations, but early when VAR started, everyone was saying it was taking
too long, but would you rather not take a little bit longer and get the decision right? You're not
in the crowd where the crowd are looking when the referee goes to the screen and it can have
an effect on how he's feeling in that moment, say you're away at Old Trafford or Man City or any of
the big clubs, but you said you're in a room, would you rather not just take a little bit more time
and get the decision right rather than rushing it and getting it wrong? 100%, Micah. I would never
want to sacrifice accuracy for the sake of speed. If we can get both, then we're in the ideal world.
If we're not taking too long, then we can be accurate. I would always say to the guys at work
in the VAR hub, do the due diligence that you need to do. You can't take shortcuts. You've got to do
it properly. You've got to look at the angles that you need to look at. I don't want them looking at
the same angle seven, eight times. That's not something that's clearly wrong if they're having
to do that. They might need to look at seven different angles once or twice because it might
be the seventh angle that shows you the very clear image that you guys will show on match of the day
because you've got people who are looking for that angle. We have to find that angle in the
moment before it's too late, before the game's restarted. Sometimes they need to do that.
One of the things that I think is really beneficial of us going out and showing how the
process works is that people understand the camera angles that we've got to look at. They understand
why it might take a bit of time, why the referee stood on the field with a finger to the rear,
not allowing the restart to happen. We want to be as least interfering as we can be. I want as
many goals that are scored to be allowed to stand so people can celebrate knowing that there's only
a really small chance of that goal being taken away. If it's allowed to stand, it'll be a good
goal. The team that's conceded know it's a fair goal. We want to be really accurate 100% of the
time if that's possible. That's the ambition, but also do it in an efficient way, but never sacrifice
the accuracy for the speed. By the way, just to dispel another myth as well, when the referee
goes to the screen, they can absolutely keep their decision if they want to. Sometimes the VAR gets
it wrong. They're sitting in this somewhat sterile environment watching a screen from
some distance away from the smell and the feel and the atmosphere of the game. Therefore,
they might recommend a review for the referee to go over. The referee might look at it and say,
honestly, I don't know what you're seeing, but there's no expectation based on my feeling of
what I saw at the time, the feeling I'm getting from the players and what I'm seeing now to
change that decision. Thanks a lot for recommending the review, but I'm going to keep my call. Now,
it shouldn't happen too often if the VARs are good at recognizing clear errors because normally
you'd go over and say, yep, that is a clear error. I agree and I'm going to change it.
They are absolutely entitled to keep their decision if they feel that's the right thing to do.
In terms of the fans, Howard, there's a feeling around the country that sometimes the big clubs,
and I think Micah alluded to it slightly, sometimes the big clubs seem to get their way.
Obviously Manchester United on Monday. I presume you'd absolutely deny there's any truth in that,
but that's the question that fans would expect me to ask.
Yeah. There's that perception. I hear it from fans I speak to, I hear it on radio shows that
I listen to as I'm driving around and also on podcasts like this, but also when I speak to
clubs, I sometimes get that level that is from clubs that kind of sit outside the traditional
top six. Usually what I do, I end up giving a balanced view with the clubs that I'm visiting
to show things that have gone for and against. Honestly speaking, things generally speaking,
kind of even out in terms of the things that go for and against. I've seen some
situations go for teams that would be considered the bigger ones and we saw that on Monday night,
but equally I've seen ones go in the favour of teams. I remember we got some criticism last
year for, there was a really tough weekend. You remember the one in February and we had
three situations in one weekend. One was the Crystal Palace Brighton situation where the
lines weren't placed in the right place due to some process errors and we're trying to ensure
that the process is absolutely embedded with our officials through the increased training.
The same day Brentford scored against Arsenal, Norgard was offside and there was a bit of a
complicated check just before that. We were trying to get some lines placed on a possible
interfering with the opponent and then that put pressure on the VAR, sped up through the rest of
the attacking phase and missed Norgard coming back from an offside position. Then also the same day,
Chelsea felt they should have had a penalty against West Ham. I think it was Suchek and
went down to his left to try to block a shot with his knee and it ended up saving it with his hand.
It was a good save. That was two situations that went against two of what we would consider the
biggest six, if you like, in Chelsea and Arsenal. The stats don't always bear out the perception,
but I know the perception exists. Again, one of my biggest challenges is to try to change the way
that things are perceived, I think. The more that I can give real information that I think is
insightful and interesting, then the better because I think that shows the real picture
rather than just what people perceive. Howard, I know that you yourself or your
organisation can't change the laws. You're guided by IFAB. That's correct in what I'm saying, yes?
Yeah, that's right. How would you personally like to deliver the handball law? Because I personally
feel that's one of the biggest issues in our game and I think it's most confusing in our game and I
think that's where there's a lot of inconsistency in our game and that's what angers players, fans,
managers, coaches. How would you personally like to see the handball law? How would you like to see
it delivered? It's a really good question and you saw my reaction when you asked the question.
Handball is the most subjective area, the area where we struggle to get the most consistency.
It used to be all right, Howard. It used to be okay and back in the day it used to use a bit
of common sense and you could tell there was an element of whether it's deliberate or not,
but now it's got so complex, hasn't it? Yeah, and we've seen more changes in this
part of the law than anywhere else, Gary. Do you know, I think that's the answer. Just go back to
allowing the referee to determine if something is a deliberate handball.
The difficulty is that obviously in a lot of your handball situations do we see a player moving
their hand towards the ball? In fact, it happens rarely, doesn't it? How many times the defenders
truly deliberately handle the ball in the penalty area? Most times it's either something they've
kind of like they've just flapped it ahead and their arms up and bizarrely they flick it away
with their hand under pressure from an opponent or they go to block a ball, but they put their arms
out in a position which kind of does increase their body size and they get an advantage from
that because the position of the arm blocks the shot. Even if they were trying to do it with their
chest or their leg, they get this advantage from the arms being away from the body. So they're not
going into that challenge thinking, I'm going to try and block this with my arm. You know,
the few exceptions would be like the Suarez one in the 2010 World Cup, he flicks over the bar.
They're few and far between. They're generally trying to get their arms out of the way.
Yeah, exactly. So I think that's why we've got in the situation where we are.
The way that the law is written is try to accommodate those situations where players
don't mean to do it, but they do and they get an advantage from doing it. But it's hard. It's hard
to judge because what's natural and what's not natural depends on so many different variables,
doesn't it? And therefore, I think probably the more kind of extreme the arm positions are,
the more credible a penalty decision would be. I don't think we can only say we'll penalize only
when players deliberately move their hands to the ball because that would leave a lot of situations
where you guys, I imagine, would say, yeah, that has to be a penalty. Look at the arm position.
It's in a really unnatural place. He's got a big advantage from that. So I think moving a little
bit away from where we've been recently around too many handball penalties being given, we've
tried to ease back a little bit in that respect, allowing the referee to make a judgment as to
whether the arm position is really totally unjustified. But I think we're better being
in a place where we only penalize when it is totally unjustified. And if it's in the margins,
give the benefit of the doubt to the defender unless you see that movement. What I wouldn't
want, and I have heard it mentioned, what I wouldn't want is a situation where we penalize
every contact with the arm simply because I just think that players would start to just
drive the ball towards players arms. I just think that it would be the target rather than the goal.
