It's probably easier to play as arm than it is to at the back of the net. So let's drive our
shot towards or our cross towards the defender. And then it'd be a game of dodgeball, wouldn't it?
Howard, I just want to finish on a point that I think is very important.
I think I've experienced a lot of football inside the stadium with VAR and from a fan's perspective,
you do not know what is going on. All you see is a review of so-and-so and you sit there for two
minutes and you wait a decision. When do you think it will come that will, I know it started in the
Women's World Cup, we've started that slight explanation of a decision at the end, but
we need to hear the conversation that goes on between the referee and the VAR. Like you get
in other sports, cricket, rugby, for example, is that going to come? Because at the moment,
I think it's not fair on the fans, particularly in the stadium.
Yeah, and they're the most important fans of all going out there with respect to the TV audience,
the ones who are in the stadium, creating the atmosphere, the ones that you played in front of
and I officiated in front of that give you that great feeling when you walk out at five to three.
Yeah, we need to be better in that respect. And it's not been easy enough to crack a
think and trying to work out how to communicate because what's happening at the minute is not
enough. We need to do more in stadium. So I think that what we're seeing down in Australia,
New Zealand will expand into some domestic leagues as early as the next few weeks.
I heard actually only a few days ago that it's not only when they go to the screen that they
can make the announcement, they're actually now enabled towards the back end of the tournament,
they allow the officials to speak as well when a check is happening before you actually go to the
screen. That's when sometimes you're still there with the finger to the ear to say, you know,
we are checking for a possible act of violent conduct by number six or a possible offside by
number 10 or whatever. So I think that's useful as well. I think that's the direction that
most leagues will take. We'll have a conversation with the Premier League and any other leagues that
take VAR on. I think the Women's Super League might be taking the VAR system on board at some
point soon and the Football League are looking closely at it. The other aspect is the TV
broadcaster. So when I was in MLS, we opened up the broadcast, the audio to broadcast for a few
games. We were told not to do that by FIFA until approval had been given. So we set up a working
group and I'm still on this working group that's looking at how we can do that better because
we've got absolutely nothing to hide. We've played it out to the TV audience on shows, on Sky and on
other channels as well. And we've also done it to the broadcasters behind the scenes. I know some
of you guys have been on those calls where we've played the audio to you so you can hear what's
been said. So big fans of opening up as much information as possible. An example of that is
we've started now running the clock in the stadium beyond 45 and 90 minutes, which is, I think we're
the first league or leagues in the world to do that. I made a phone call and said, look, this is
nonsensical. We're holding up seven minutes on the board. Fans don't know how long beyond 90 minutes
has gone. The whistling from two or three minutes in, players are asking how long's left. Just show
people. Let's treat people in the way they deserve to be treated in terms of the information sharing
so they can see that we've only played five minutes. We've got another two to go. People
understand there's going to be another minute on top of that if we've had a goal or a substitution.
So let's just do things right. Let's open up the information and let's bring this game
kicking and screaming into the 21st century. Well, Howard, thank you very much for talking to us.
This is an exact example of how things can help towards people's understanding of what
VAR is and how referees and how difficult it is and communication,
I think, is really important. So thank you so much for your time. Alan and Michael as well,
thank you. And we'll say goodbye to everyone until the next time.
Thanks very much, Howard. Really appreciate it.
Thanks, guys. Great to see you.
Cheers, Howard. Goodbye.
Bye.
